speaker: James
text: [dry] Hinkley Point. Eighteen billion quid. A shining example of strategic foresight, or a monument to the triumph of short-term interests?

speaker: Elena
text: Oh, come on, James. The UK needs baseload power. It needs energy security. And it certainly needed to keep China sweet, post-Brexit.

speaker: James
text: Keep China sweet with subsidies paid by the British public for 45 years? For a plant whose price doubled and whose technology looks increasingly risky?

speaker: Elena
text: But the jobs, the investmentâ€”

speaker: James
text: Forget the jobs for a second. The article makes a rather stark point: it's about *who* makes these decisions and *who* ultimately pays.

speaker: Elena
text: You're talking about your 'Beams and Columns' theory, aren't you?

speaker: James
text: Precisely. The supranational 'Beam' people who designed it, and the 'Column' people who will foot the bill. It's a useful lens for understanding the political landscape.

speaker: Elena
text: That's a bit simplistic, isn't it? Dividing society into global elites and local workers. It feels like a caricature.

speaker: James
text: Is it? The article cites British people with American degrees working for Arabian banks in Dubai. Or Pakistanis from Stanford working for Citigroup then the World Bank.

speaker: Elena
text: So, if you travel for work, you're a Beam? If you stay put, you're a Column? That can't be the entire story.

speaker: James
text: [thoughtful] It's about outlook and economic ties. Beams benefit from free flow of capital and people, often undermine home country competitiveness. Columns are tied to place, to local economies, to government spending.

speaker: Elena
text: I can see the distinction, especially when you talk about the 70-90% of jobs outside London linked to government funds. That's... actually quite devastating.

speaker: James
text: Yes. And those Column people are the ones paying the Hinkley Point subsidies. Funds that could have gone to their schools or hospitals.

speaker: Elena
text: [frustrated] But there's a national strategic need! We can't just rely on solar and wind when the sun doesn't shine and the wind doesn't blow. Baseload is critical.

speaker: James
text: Right. But ten years to build it? In ten years, renewables will likely need no subsidies at all. Battery technology will fix intermittency. The article makes that clear.

speaker: Elena
text: Wait, really? No subsidies?

speaker: James
text: [emphatic] Solar power is already the cheapest form of electricity in sunnier parts of the world. Wind and solar are *significantly* cheaper and less risky than nuclear now.

speaker: Elena
text: Okay, that's harder to argue with. If the numbers are so stark, why did they go ahead?

speaker: James
text: Because Beam people conceived it. Politicians, engineers, financiers, lawyers. All making good money from it. It's in their short-term interest.

speaker: Elena
text: So you're saying it's pure self-interest, disguised as national interest?

speaker: James
text: The article's pretty blunt: 'Beam people know this. They are well educated and informed. They are doing something that is in their best short term interest but is not in the best interest of their country and their fellow citizens in the long run.'

speaker: Elena
text: That's a damning indictment. It links directly to why so many feel the system is 'rigged,' as the article states.

speaker: James
text: Indeed. Trump, Brexit. These weren't accidents. They were a reaction from Column people. Remember when you called those voters 'seemingly unconnected'? Hinkley helps us connect them.

speaker: Elena
text: I suppose... the idea of paying subsidies to France and China for decades, for something cheaper alternatives exist for now, and will dominate later... that's a tough sell.

speaker: James
text: It's a particularly tough sell when you consider other countries are already outmanoeuvring us. China, for instance, in our 'China Has Many Of The Characteristics Of An Emerging Colonial Power' piece.

speaker: Elena
text: So Hinkley isn't just a bad deal financially, it's also a symbol of how the Beam mindset undermines national sovereignty, or at least national wealth, over the long term.

speaker: James
text: Exactly. Just as the Treaty of Tordesillas in 'The Scramble For The Solar System' was ignored by rising powers, these long-term commitments can prove incredibly shortsighted.

speaker: Elena
text: It feels like a slow, self-inflicted decline. Like in your 'Crisis: Or An Explanation On The Origins Of The Decline Of The West' article.

speaker: James
text: The Faustian bargain. Short-term knowledge, long-term soul. Or in this case, short-term contracts, long-term burden.

speaker: Elena
text: And the Column people, who are not stupid, will keep noticing. That's the real issue, isn't it? The erosion of trust.

speaker: James
text: Yes. When the system appears rigged, as it does with projects like this, eventually the Column people push back. And that pushback often isn't rational or predictable.

speaker: Elena
text: So, what's the solution? Forcing Beams to act more responsibly? Or empowering Columns to make better decisions?

speaker: James
text: [amused] Good luck with both. But understanding the divide is the first step. Hinkley Point simply highlights how deep it runs.
